title: Bosses warn Government's economic plan hinges on Heathrow runway
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 21:14 BST - UK Markets closed Bosses warn Government's economic plan hinges on Heathrow runway By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 13 minutes ago 1,466.00 +25.00 
Next (Other OTC: NXGPF - news ) boss Lord Wolfson and WPP (LSE: WPP.L - news ) chief Sir Martin Sorrell join 58 other leaders by in signing a letter to the Government 
Next boss Lord Wolfson, WPP chief Sir Martin Sorrell, and George Weston, the boss of Primark-owner Associated British Foods (LSE: ABF.L - news ) , have warned the Prime Minister that the credibility of his Government’s long-term economic plan is at risk if he does not allow a third runway at Heathrow. 
The corporate heavyweights have joined 57 other business leaders, including Aberdeen Asset Management (Other OTC: ABDNF - news ) boss Martin Gilbert and ICAP (LSE: IAP.L - news ) chief Michael Spencer, in signing a letter urging ministers to “give the green light as soon as possible” to a new runway in west London . 
“The new government was elected upon a mandate to invest in national infrastructure,” says the letter, which was organised by the Let Britain Fly lobby group and sent to the prime minister and the members of the cabinet committee set up to decide on airport expansion. 
“If the UK’s long-term economic plan is to remain credible then allowing investment into the construction of a new runway is essential.” 
At the start of the month, the government-appointed Airports Commission concluded that the “best answer” to solving Britain’s aviation capacity crisis is another runway at Heathrow. The proposal is controversial among local communities, however, and faces fierce opposition because of worries residents will be blighted by higher air pollution and increased noise. 
Five members of David Cameron’s cabinet are thought to be against Heathrow expansion, as well as vocal Conservatives Boris Johnson and Zac Goldsmith. But Graham Brady, the chairman of the Tories’ influential 1922 Committee, has suggested that other MPs are overwhelmingly in favour of the runway . 
The government should set out “a clear timetable for an early parliamentary vote to take place by summer 2016”, the letter says, so that Britain can catch-up with rival airports at Paris, Frankfurt and Dubai. 
“We are becoming less competitive as a global aviation hub at a time when our competitors have plans to build over fifty new runways globally.”
